# Introduction {.unnumbered}

This website contains an evolving thematic catalogue of Gregor Joseph Werner's works.

::: {.callout-caution}
## Caution

As of v0.12.0, work numbers are considered **stable and citable**. Nevertheless, this catalogue is still work-in-progress, and minor changes are to be expected. A [development version](https://dev.gregor-joseph-werner.at/) is available.
:::

For general and biographical information on Werner, see @Bogati1936, @Czernin2020, @Moder1959, @Moder1985, @Petermayr2007, @Tank1981 [p. 168-189], and @Unverricht2001.


## Overview

We classify Werner's works as *Vocal music* (groups A to L) and *instrumental music* (groups M to Q). Groups D, H, and I are further divided into subgroups to provide a more fine-grained classification and to preserve work numbering if further works are discovered. Within each (sub-)group, works are ordered by library and siglum; the more important libraries (H-Bn and A-Ed) appear first, followed by other libraries. Following works with ascertained authorship, lost works (prefix L followed by consecutive number) and spurious and uncertain attributions (prefix S followed by consecutive number) are included.


**Vocal music** comprises

- *A. Oratorios*
- *B. Masses*
- *C. Requiems*
- *D. Short liturgical works*<br/>
  (1) Motets<br/>
  (2) Offertories<br/>
  (3) Responsories<br/>
  (4) Rorates<br/>
  (5) Miscellaneous works
- *E. German sacred music*
- *F. Hymns*
- *G. Litanies*
- *H. Vespers and psalms*<br/>
  (1) Complete vespers<br/>
  (2) Psalms<br/>
  (3) Magnificats
- *I. Marian antiphons*<br/>
  (1) Alma redemptoris mater<br/>
  (2) Ave Regina coelorum<br/>
  (3) Regina coeli<br/>
  (4) Salve Regina<br/>
  (5) Sub tuum praesidium
- *J. Te Deums*
- *K. Lamentations*
- *L. Profane vocal music*

**Instrumental music** comprises

- *M. Sonatas*
- *N. Pastorellas*
- *O. Partitas*
- *P. Sinfonias*
- *Q. Concertos*

The catalogue contains at least the following information for each work:

- title
- one or more incipits
- identifiers in other catalogues
- [Archival Resource Key](#arks)
- sources (linked to the respective RISM entry, if available)
- miscellaneous notes
- relevant literature
- modern editions [@Czernin2020b]

In addition, we are annotating more and more works with [detailed metadata](metadata.qmd) in MEI format [@MEI2023].

Works in the catalogue should be cited by the abbreviation “WerW”, followed by the group, subgroup (if applicable), and work number; the latter three components should be separated by a period.

As a supplement to the catalogue, we publish selected works as [Open Content editions](https://edition.esser-skala.at/scores/gregor-joseph-werner/). Available works are marked with the symbol ![](images/ees_link_light.svg) in the work details.


### Works/sources not yet catalogued

- CZ-Bm: according to the inventories of Straková and Kyas, several funds should comprise works by a composer named Werner:
  - 11 (Brno - klášter minoritů)
  - 84 (Rajhrad u Brna)
  - 109 (Znojmo - Městská hudební škola)
  - 5 (Brno – Tuřany)
- CZ-NR: Aria de Passione Domini
- H-Bn: (Ms. Mus. 179)[https://nektar.oszk.hu/hu/manifestation/2707932] (“Vesperae brevissimae e quatro offertorii per li evangelii nel festo del Corpus Domini”)



## Methods

### Sources

The following sources represent previous efforts to create a thematic catalogue:

@Harich1932, @Muranyi1997
: In the 1930s, János Hárich catalogued the holdings of Werner's works in the Esterházy archives (now in the National Széchényi Library, H-Bn). This typewritten catalogue is available, e.g., in the archive of the Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde (siglum 14801/102). Róbert Árpád Murányi later published a transcription of the catalogue with additional notes and incipits. Notably, Murányi arranged the works by their shelfmark. By contrast, Hárich grouped the works into 18 sections (by genre) and numbered them consecutively within each section (mostly, but not always, following the order of the shelfmark).

@Reichert1935
: In his seminal PhD that catalogued more than 400 masses kept in Viennese and surrounding archives, Georg Reichert also included incipits for twenty masses by Werner. Notably, he only considered manuscripts in the Austrian National Library, Göttweig, Heiligenkreuz, and the archive of the Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde.

@Harich1990
: Hárich also worked on a thematic catalogue of Werner's works, which was archived as part of his nachlass by the Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde (Nachlass Hárich, fascicle 19). This catalogue consists of an introduction (DIN A4, 18 p.) and ca. 600 index cards (DIN A5), each of which describes one work. Several crossed out numbers on these cards indicate that the catalogue was revised several times, but eventually remained unfinished. In its archived form, the catalogue describes 677 works in total, but contains several duplicate entries and omits some works that were discovered later.

@WinklerKlement2013
: In her diploma thesis, Susanne Winkler-Klement catalogued manuscripts of Werner's works in the archive of the Eisenstadt cathedral (A-Ed) and the State Museum Burgenland (A-El). Some manuscripts from the former archhive are missing in her catalogie, since they have been newly discovered and assigned in later years, i.e., during the digitization of the Eisenstadt music inventory in 2017 and 2018 [@Dolezal2018], and by chance in the storage room of the parish office on 2017-06-20 [@Meyer2020b].

@Petermayr2024
: An unpublished draft catalogue of works by Klaus Petermayr (personal communication).


Partial catalogues of Werner's works are available in

- @Dopf1956 – masses
- @Harich1976 – oratorios
- @Mikusi2020 – sonatas
- @Petermayr2015 – German church arias and pastorellas
- @Petermayr2020 – instrumental works
- @WinklerKlement2020 – masses and oratorios


Finally, the following sources also contain hints on Werner's music:

- @Czernin2020a – overview of sources in Austria
- @Eitner1904 – sources known around 1900
- @Harich1975 – instrumental works in the historical Esterházy inventories


### Workflow

The work list assembled from these sources (`data/catalogue_works.csv`) was checked against and supplemented by RISM entries. To this end, entries were downloaded via [*sru-downloader*](https://github.com/rism-international/sru-downloader) on 2024-01-27, yielding 867 entries. In the resulting XML file, all tags in the `zs` namespace were removed, yielding the XML file `data/rism_entries.xml`, which only contains [MarcXML](https://www.loc.gov/standards/marcxml/) tags:

```bash
java -jar SRUDownloader.jar "https://muscat.rism.info/sru/sources?operation=searchRetrieve&version=1.1&query=creator=%22Werner,%20Gregor%20Joseph%22&maximumRecords=100"
grep -v "<zs:" output.xml | \
  grep -v "</zs:" | \
  grep -v "<marc:collection" | \
  grep -v "</marc:collection" | \
  sed '1 a\<marc:collection xmlns:marc="http://www.loc.gov/MARC21/slim">' | \
  sed '$ a\</marc:collection>' \
  > rism_entries.xml
rm output.xml
```

Later changes in the RISM database were manually added to the catalogue (2025-02-09: 875 entries for “Werner, Gregor Joseph” and 5 (A-Z) entries for “Werner, C.”). Pages for all groups of works were generated automatically from `catalogue_overview.csv` and `catalogue_works.csv`. If manually curated incipits were unavailable for a work, the first incipit of the first source with a RISM entry was included. Data from the [RISM Catalogue](https://opac.rism.info) (e.g., Plaine & Easie Code for incipits) by the *Répertoire International des Sources Musicales* is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution CC-BY 3.0 Unported License.

Detailed work metadata was edited with [MerMEId v2.0](https://mermeid.edirom.de/). Incipits were either prepared with [MuseScore](https://musescore.org), polished with [mei-friend](https://mei-friend.mdw.ac.at), and rendered with [Verovio](https://www.verovio.org), or created with [LilyPond](https://lilypond.org/) and [EES Tools](https://github.com/edition-esser-skala/ees-tools). XML files were exported from MerMEId, post-processed and validated against the schema [mei-CMN](https://github.com/music-encoding/schema/blob/main/4.0.0/mei-CMN.rng). These pages are rendered using the [BravuraText](https://github.com/steinbergmedia/bravura) font v1.392 and Verovio.

The technical workflow has been presented as a [poster](/publications/poster_iaml_2025.pdf) at the IAML Conference 2025 in Salzburg.


### ARKs

A semi-opaque Archival Resource Key ([ARK](https://arks.org)) is assigned to each work as persistent identifier:

- Each ARK uses the Name Assigning Authority Number ([NAAN](https://arks.org/about/ark-naans-and-systems/)) `68748` …
 - … and the [Shoulder](https://arks.org/about/ark-features/) `gw1`.
 - The [Blade](https://arks.org/specs/) consists of the catalogue of work number (lowercase, no separators).

Thus, the ARKs [ark:68748/gw1b1](https://n2t.net/ark:68748/gw1b1) and [ark:68748/gw1d5s1](https://n2t.net/ark:68748/gw1d5s1) denote WerW B.1 and D.5.S1, respectively.

ARKs are resolved by `https://ark.esser-skala.at` via a [minimal ARK resolver](https://github.com/edition-esser-skala/minimal-ark-resolver). (They are also forwarded to the resolver from this site's base URL via its `.htaccess` file.) The resolver supports the following features:

- The object variant `.mei` directly resolves to the metadata in MEI format.<br/>
Example: [ark:68748/gw1b1.mei](https://n2t.net/ark:68748/gw1b1.mei)
- The inflection `?info` yields a brief metadata record following the [Dublin Kernel](https://www.dublincore.org/groups/kernel/spec/) specification, including a persistence statement using the [NLM vocabulary](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/pubs/techbull/ma05/ma05_archive.html).<br/>
Examples: [ark:68748/gw1b1?info](https://n2t.net/ark:68748/gw1b1?info) and [ark:68748/gw1b1.mei?info](https://n2t.net/ark:68748/gw1b1.mei?info)



### Data and code availability

Datasets and code used for preparing this catalogue are available from [GitHub](https://github.com/edition-esser-skala/werner-catalogue-of-works).
